    AGP and Episodes

    AGP_and_Episodes.Rmd

    The iglu package includes two single page reports - an ambulatory glucose profile (AGP), and an episode calculation report.

    Ambulatory Glucose Profile (AGP)

    The iglu package allows one to generate an Ambulatory Glucose Profile (AGP) report - see Johnson (2019) “Utilizing the ambulatory glucose profile to standardize and implement continuous glucose monitoring in clinical practice.”. Below is an example report for Subject 1, which includes information on data collection period, time spent in standardized glycemic ranges (cutoffs of 54, 70, 180 and 250 mg/dL) displayed as a stacked bar chart, glucose variability as measured by %CV, and visualization of quantiles of the glucose profile across days together with daily glucose views.

    agp(example_data_1_subject)

    Episode Calculation

    The Episode_Calculation function measures the number of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia that occur more than a certain period.

    episode_calculation(example_data_5_subject, hypo_thres=100.0, hyper_thres= 120.0, dur_length = 15)
#> # A tibble: 5 x 11
#>   id     Average_Glucose Hypo_ep Hyper_ep hypo_duration hyper_duration Hypo_mean
#>   <fct>            <dbl>   <dbl>    <dbl>         <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>
#> 1 Subje…            125.  2.79       2.64         111.            197.    215.  
#> 2 Subje…            221.  0.0769     1.15          50             965.      7.32
#> 3 Subje…            156.  1.14       3.71          66.7           288.    106.  
#> 4 Subje…            132.  2.43       4.71          93.3           219.    206.  
#> 5 Subje…            172.  1          2.42          96.6           534.     91.1 
#> # … with 4 more variables: Hyper_mean <dbl>, low_alert <dbl>, high_alert <dbl>,
#> #   target_range <dbl>

    Users can set certain thresholds for the hypo and hyperglycemia by passing parameters. Here, we are passing 100 for the hypoglycemia threshold and 120 for the hyperglycemia threshold. By setting a duration length to 15 minutes (the last parameter), the function will count the number of episodes that glucose values go below or above the thresholds more than 15 minutes.

    In this example, we calculated episodes for multiple subjects. The average numbers of hypo and hyperglycemia for subject 1 are 2.7 and 2.6 respectively. It occurred for 111 minutes and 196 minutes in average. You can also see other values such as the mean value of glucose, hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia, and this function can be used for a single subject as well.

    Epicalc_profile function

    Visualization of the metrics produced by the episode_calculation() function is done with the function epicalc_profile(). This function takes the episode_calculation() output and displays it as a tables of the episode metrics as well as plots that visualizes the subject’s glucose level over time. Like episode_calculation, this function is designed to work with one subject data at a time, and the structure of the function output is shown below.

    epicalc_profile(example_data_1_subject)

    The function will accept the following three parameters that are passed on to epicalc_profile(). Like episode_calculation(), there are options to adjust the hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia thresholds. If the hyperglycemia threshold is lower than the hypoglycemia threshold, a warning will be produced. * “hypo_thres” - Threshold for what below is considered hypoglycemia. Default is 90 and the units are mg/dL * “hyper_thres” - Threshold for what above is considered hyperglycemia. Default is 120 and the units are mg/dL * “color_scheme = c("blue-red", "red-orange")” - String corresponding to a color scheme for the plot. Default is blue-red The ‘red-orange’ color scheme corresponds to red for hypoglycemia, orange for hyperglycemia, and green for in between. The ‘blue-red’ corresponds to blue for hypoglycemia, red for hyperglycemia, and white for in between.

    epicalc_profile(example_data_1_subject, 40, 120, color_scheme = ('red-orange'))
